13KOMqSezz6roKEznYoz4w.text: It's not authentic Asian food but I was longing some spicy noodles and was in the area. I had the chicken chili men and it hit the spot - spicy and very tasty. I liked the communal table (altho I think a lot of London Asian eateries are going that direction) and the service was good. I'd definitely visit again...

rygJ94BljbENLyz3T1-eIg.text: It has been three years since I was in London, and I haven't stopped dreaming about Wagamama. As a broke student, Wagamama was a dining staple for us. This particular restaurant was our favorite, particularly because of its proximity to the cinema, theatres, and shops, but we were also seen having lunch one or two times a week at the Camden Town location, close to our school. I have had wonderful ramen at interesting restaurants since coming back to the States, but nothing has compared to Wagamama's. At first, we were on a mission to find the Wagamama equivalent in the United States, and ate at all the ramen places we could find. After accepting that better ramen does not exist outside of the UK, we dreamed and schemed about convincing Wagamama corporate to let us open a franchise in Los Angeles (hey, if Tesco could do it, why couldn't we?). I think we've come to the realization that we'll have to return to London to enjoy Wagamama again. However, if they ever do come to the United States, I hope that LA is their first stop.And I hope they still have the duck gyoza. Those were really good.

AYlch8Z4JwCBuBgPwPe26w.text: Good place with nice noodles and decent food but really nothing special. You eat well and is good price for what you get. I recommend if you are looking for 'fast/fresh food' like food in an Asian style.

pVVP6P5-NfOD84o4AjFylw.text: veggie soba was delish --perfectly seasoned, perfect place to sit down after walking -- although i wish they had outdoor patio seating like the neighbouring restaurants... but i read about this in a 2004 best of europe guide, and i'm glad this place is still around after 5 years... now i know why. :)the broth was like crack soup, (can i say that here?) i couldn't stop drinking it, and i wasn't very hungry to start with!for about £8 i had the big bowl of stri fried veggies on top of soba in a ramen broth with green tea, and i left a very happy customer :)

GV5pS8tZdiC1iKuoTKuCtQ.text: A place not to be missed!  I've eaten at many of the locations from in Turkey, London and Ireland and am so glad they've come to the US!   YUM!

JB2R_OEE8YInO5_MGKG_bw.text: delicious ramen!  even though it is ridiculously priced for a bowl of ramen compared to the us or japan, it's quite a delight.the chicken chili ramen and the yaki udon are my favorites here.you can find this wagamama in leicester square.  the seating is kind of like a cafeteria style seating and the servers are really nice.  the best part is you can get tickets for a show right after your meal.

WJu-44xsJU0Q6I37yIH3Ug.text: I wouldn't go to Wagamama because i really like it.  I would go because its decent, its clean, its relatively fresh, relatively inexpensive, and its not mcdo's or burger king or kfc.

zJWhWf3ovDuok74TxnnGWw.text: Saw Christian Bail and Huge Grant there. I had really nice lean steak on my noodles. It was delightful even in a hot day in London. Please enjoy this little part of the city.

HdxnrVyFqYtOcLx7fR5LAA.text: Nothing makes me miss home more than good homestyle cooking, which is what i was hoping for when i went to Wagamama.  Hardly authentic and by no means satisfying, their food still managed to get the job done and fill me up.  The food is bland and lacking in flavor, but filling.  It's conveniently open until late in the evening and not absurdly overpriced in true Asian fashion.

7Yhp5f4g8JH3mdm-WClxSQ.text: London is freezing! We needed something warm. There was no pho or soup place in site, so my friend's cousin (w/2 years of living in London) took us to this popular Japanese UK chain of ramen restaurants. I ordered the Miso Ramen with cha-su (sp?) pork which was actually really, really good. I believe it was for 9 pounds and came with hot unsweetened tea. The broth was perfectly miso and it had a ton of meat (a rather large bowl). The veggies were perfectly mixed in too. A sweet combination of salty and sweet broth that probably saved my frozen bones from dry-ice cracking (that's how cold the chill was that night in November). If you're cold in London, com eat here!

q5AtblWh139UzrfBesHk-g.text: Well....  This place gets pretty busy.  I think the service was ridiculous.  But what made it worth it is the food.  Chicken Katsu Curry that doesn't taste like the typical japanese curry I have in LA.   i think it's about the same level as curry house, or hurry curry.

JIGK700Oe3nS8V0ihR4_XA.text: Japanese style noodle bar. One of many chain restaurants sprinkled across London and all over the world. Actual restaurant located in the basement. Messhall style seating arrangements. Young clientele, crowded, and very noisy. Service fast and efficient. Tried Wagamama ramen and Katsu curry. Ramen broth was very flavorful; came with tenderly grilled chicken and fish. Noodles didn't have enough bite. Curry was good. Portions filling but not huge. Interesting concept as a whole and seems immensely popular with the British.

mPzrT6iLuGPts3CGD9FMBQ.text: It was cold, cold night in London after a long, exhausting trek around Central London. Being from the States, we were craving some sort of broth like soup for dinner. Good thing my cousin lives in London and took us here. I ordered the Chili Chicken Ramen, which was really tasty in a broth filled with lots of chicken and packed with flavor. I expected it to be a little bit more spicy considering it was supposed to have fresh chili in it, but it was not... My friend had the Miso Ramen, which just tasted like Ramen in a miso soup broth. He loved it though. My cousin ordered some teppan noodles. Can't remember which one exactly, but the dish was bland. Considering the fact that we were half way around the world, this restaurant made us feel right at home. The prices though, didn't, but hey, it IS London afterall...

yJaCcFdEdkmhdGZmcIHl6Q.text: I was visiting a friend in London and we'd gone out for a nice evening.  It was getting a bit late and he suggested we go to Wagamama.  Not having been before, I said sho' nuff!I'm glad he suggested it...delicious and casual noodle house and not absurdly expensive.  I'd go again next time I'm in town.

K30HtMwmyUynJ4-7dWMQiw.text: Every time I visit London I have to make a stop at Wagamama.  I even had to send a friend of mine a postcard (free at the door) from the restaurant to rub it in that I got to eat there.  Don't pass it up, definitely worth the slightly higher prices.  Yum!

q5795bAQPWdU4HTTxrIFlw.text: A smaller, cosier version of the pan-Asian restaurant chain. Alongside the long, wooden benches, there are small booths; ideal for couples or close friends to enjoy a more private meal and conversation. The food is healthy, tasty, and in my experience, served quickly even in very busy times. The staff are helpful and friendly, and seem knowledgeable with regards to the diverse menu. There is no reservation system, however, due to the relative tranquillity of this particular restaurant and the good speed of service, potential customers should not worry about waiting for a table.

MRT9UEtf-l51JeI6Wh9onA.text: Great place for a quick bite before the theatre if you love noodles and rice dishes!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

TEZFTaIqtGsg_o9RHdGKww.text: I went to Wagamama after the theater about 10 years ago and remembered it fondly, so I was looking forward to another Wagamama experience after seeing a show at the Savoy.   Unfortunately, it was a disappointment.  I ordered the steamed vegetarian gyoza, a chili vegetarian wheat noodle dish, and still water for £15.  The portions were a decent size but this had neither the authenticity of real Asian noodles nor the refinement of fusion.  The chili sauce completely overwhelmed the noodles and neither the gyoza nor the noodles were tasty.  But the service was fast and efficient.

iD0SMcoXkIQ81bTYi9S9Sw.text: This was a childhood favorite place, so when I came back, I was really excited. Unfortunately, the ramen was just okay. As I mentioned in another review, I'll eat ramen in basically any form, but I wouldn't say this is truly rant-worth ramen. It's not negative rant worthy either, though.

UzJ3tKj57rGYPK4p4v4mpg.text: In January Wagamama always has this promotion going on where you get a voucher for a meal free and even a bottle of wine. I normally do not try out such offers, but this one worked pretty well. This was the reason why my friends and I went there again. We had a nice little feast in the evening, before going to the cinema at Leicester Square.Normally, Wagamamas are situated in the basement of a store. We had to stand in a queue for a while before getting seated. The waiting time does normally not take too long, as Wagamama is known for fast food service. Not in a bad way, it is just not a place where you have a private table conversation, as you are seated on a long bench, which goes from one side of the room to the other.Already been asked by he waiters several times if we are ready, finally we chose form an extensive list of Asian food. They scribbled your order on the table set. Therefore you will be sure you will receive the right dish!We always start of with some edame - beans, which have to be popped out of their skin. They are fun to share. The dim sums I can highly recommend, they come with delicious sweet and chilli sauces. But for what they are really known are their noodle soups. I always opt for the hot option. I think Wagamama is a good after shopping or pre theatre place, as you do not want to over pay yourself nor waste too much time.There is one big advantage - this wagamama is one in three in London who does has a wheelchair lift!

2H0upBLw-DKRM8XWuXYL8g.text: I used to like Wagamama a lot. I tried it in Dublin for first time and I dined here sometimes when i moved to London... all this until my last visit. I ordered Yaki Soba and i ended up with a plate full of over seasoned noodles, salty to death..... was that positive eating-positive living? Not at all, I had drunk 5 glasses of water by the end of the meal.I dont think I will go back to Wagamama unless I only have McDonalds or Burger King as an alternative option... there are plenty of nice oriental food restaurants in London as to opt again for  this one.

Oc45rsHafnK7fiKaUkrwig.text: OKSimply OK. The problems stemmed from 3 staff serving rather a large lunch time crowd. Made to wait to be seated for way too long in an atempt to control the flow of orders. I'm making an intuitive guess. And then serving up a nice apple and ginger juice and some chicken that had been fried to death. My date, she swapped with me. She's a sexy minx who likes her chicken crispy. Me, I like it cooked just right. Then an issue that makes me an old twat. The girls aside us were headed up by one bright young thing who clearly didn't require oxygen. She talked and talked and then talked some more at volume. I was praying, atheist, for her food to arrive first. It arrived last and by then we'd got the bill. Nice server. Rubbish chicken. Good juice. Not all bad.

qthueTN00PlzPxz254tdXg.text: When I lived outside of London, I was told I had to go to Wagamama.  I'm glad I listened.  This place is outstanding, especially in a city where food isn't exactly the #1 thing.  The food was outstanding, but as all things London, expensive.  Not out of park expensive, but not cheap.  Being that its next to leicester square, it was obvious that would be the case.This is truly a great place to check out.  A chain restaurant I don't mind eating.

5N5K-B0pA3as6dvl_ha5BQ.text: Looks like this place is very popular with tourists (I too was attracted to Wagamama as a tourist just recently).  I'm sure its convenient location next to Leicester Square sure helps attract tourists too.  When I was studying in London seven years ago, I'd eat at Wagamama with a slight feeling of guilt seeing that it was both a chain and not real authentic Asian food (even at home in the States/California, I am not a big fan of Asian fusion)...but boy do I love me some Wagamama.On my most recent trip, I had the vegetarian curry and my boyfriend got the ginger chicken pan fried udon noodles.  My favorite thing at Wagamama has always been the Peach Iced Tea.  Service is always rushed and I feel frenzied when ordering but staff is always super attentive.  On crowded days, you'll be seated cramped right next to other patrons but I never mind.I still eat at this uber trendy restaurant with guilt, but always leave satisfied :)

jpiC5hN7cYpFHP8H_v0sbA.text: This place was great!!Growing up in Southern California means eating an Ethnically Diverse Cuisine!! So after working in Birmingham and staying in a hotel surviving off hotel food for a week I was in desperate need of something besides beans and bread...I had great fish, chips, and beer at a little pub but my desire for something non-European based was starting to drive me freakin' crazy!! ahhhh!! So, my husband flew in and we went to London for a couple days and thank God he knew of Wagamama!! I was a little skeptical about eating Japanese food in London, I knew the Indian food was pretty good but I never heard anyone saying anything like "wow the Japanese food in London Rocks!!" The only real compliments on food in London I've heard were on the fish and chips and the Indian food. That being said, "Hello, go to Wagamama for great noodles!!!!"  I had a cup of miso soup which was good and a really great bowl of ramen noodles with lots of mushrooms, and some sort of spicy pepper, (I think it was the Yasai Chili Men) and it was awesome!! So, if you're ever in London and you want something besides pub grub...check out Wagamama!! Don't forget to send your friends a free postcard (they're pretty cool)!

H9C7dbzvmIXGmj5KOVQ1iA.text: Yum Yum Yum!I loved Wagamama! The food was delicious, I loved the contemporary Asian decor, and the communal seating gave it a surprisingly warm feel. The ginger chicken udon was amazing and you could even order it with whole wheat noodles, which earned major bonus points in my book. The food was moderately priced but around the standard Central London range.I'm not giving it 5 stars because the service was so-so and our waiter wasn't the friendliest person. The restaurant was busy but I at least like a smile and kind greeting from my waiter when eating out.

vMSakn-WqyB1J3LxGijliQ.text: Was told one of places i HAD to go before I left London. "Representative of British fare" - some other American who presumably never ate Black Pudding. Don't get me wrong. Not bad. Not bad at all. But coming from Northern California where Asian food might as well be local fare, I've had better. The dining experience is fun and worth it in itself, reminiscent of elementary school playground tables. Strike up a conversation with a stranger! You'll come to a conclusion that British are friendlier than you thought, but I guarantee you just argued Gordon Brown policies with a foreigner rather than an actual Brit. Go for the noodles. I believe there's 4-5 specialty noodle dishes, pick one. They're good, at least one of them is, I can attest to that. Decently priced.

nqw1537fl5M-FXGRzEIMog.text: It's not too expensive, and the noodles are pretty good (as is the sake).  Very happy to see that they've expanded to Boston.

asNmnXz9rT7JpJuvuX408w.text: If I had any choice, I'd rather never come here again..but these places are everywhere! If it weren't for convenience, I probably wouldn't go if I had a choice..The noodles aren't authentic (not their aim, but still, it's so bad that it grates against my principles of good noodles...) and the curries and everything else aren't all that great either.Like I said, the only pluses this place has is convenience for a quick bite.PS - This review is not specific to this restaurant, they all seem to be at the same crappy level.

9syV9bfzSRtSN7w8JV49Bg.text: This Wagas (as I like to call it) doesn't offer anything special by way of stunning views of London (like you get with their Southbank branch) or different menu/service options to all their other outlets but what it does offer is a fantastic location for a pre-theatre meal. This venue is right in the heart of Theatreland and for speedy, cheap and tasty nosh before dashing off to a show I don't think you can go wrong with Wagamama. I must give a big thumbs up their house red wine too, which is rather delicious and gulpable for a house wine. And the management get a special mention at this location too for always responding well if there's any issue with the food. (Also no problem here to order extra lashings of their secret curry sauce, always bonus!). Don't miss the entrance to this place (it's in the basement) as you walk down Irving St from Leicester Sq and even if they are queuing up the stairs (as they often are from 7ish), the queues go down quickly as will your food!

7Ar0QEdQXXswH-BYY9sMvQ.text: First visit to London, first place for food. I could not have picked a better place to go after 10 hours on a plane. Food is more than I could have hoped for, provided you are looking for a "Noodle" experience. On a cold London morning, nothing was more refreshing than the saien soba. Highly recommended.

vm_DLsDg32SfMsa2rl7roA.text: ah, my most frequented wagamama location, evar. (it'd be a different story if y'all expanded to california, HINT HINT.) and by most frequented, i mean twice. lolbut definitely a great location, and the service and food are pretty much standard wagamama (and by standard wagamama, i'm basing that on all four times i've been to one). the two times i've eaten here we got here early and didn't have to wait, but it was clear that by 7:00 or so, you may have to wait a bit. oh yes! for all y'all non-brits, try the elderflower drink! it's really delish! sounds mighty sketch, but i guarantee you, you will be pleasantly surprised.p.s. don't forget that there's under-table storage for bags and what not.

vyH5sSz2zcjis5aR-WHEvg.text: As a stranger in a strange city, and country for that matter, It can be a struggle to get the most out of the eating experience simply because one doesn't know where to go. At least Wagamama was decent. I suppose I am spoiled by great Asian food in my home city of Chicago and I know that Wagamama is a chain resteraunt. So, while it was good and filled me up, it still didn't compare to my cheap, whole in the wall, neighborhood, Asian greasy spoon. The flavors were rather mild and uninspired, but we were hungry and it satisfied a need.

NZvqveCsDnRMzp_ktHNepg.text: Was a great experience especially dining on my own. The staff were very friendly although I did get a little weirded out by the guy leaning over and writing on my placemat but it was not a big deal. I particularly liked the Duck Gyoze. Probably a good place to go at night as it is all indoor and away from the street. Not the place to eat if you want to people watch.

4pIfdaJSknmrFc-ZVyyVZw.text: I had a lot of fun here.  Different atmosphere, but with Urban Belly in Chicago, am getting more accustomed to communal dining.  Great fast, fresh LARGE noddle/soup portions - delicious, affordable and entertaining for a quick bite.  Not a quiet place, though.

aHuZOotC4c9uqJF33zHblw.text: Ordered the beef teriakyi noodles and the duck dumplings and they were both great.       First place in a while with American style service, where they checked if I needed more to drink!  Fun place, and good if you're dining alone.

EQJLKkIdzK8We-1V-x6RcA.text: It's a wonder my favorite restaurant in London is a chain, but I'm somehow addicted to its savory sweetness of its teriyaki yaki soba! And now you can get it with your choice of noodles.  I tried rice noodles and it was just as delicious as with the original wheat noodles (and prob easier in my stomach!) The beef was medium rare, but it was a bit chewy (taste was still wonderful).   The free green tea is a nice touch. This location is underground so it feels a bit dark, but the staff is lovely and keeps the sometimes long queue moving along!

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Teriyaki yaki soba with sirloin steak and rice noodles (you get your choice)

zMuWzT_zxZMR8RDoESF3PQ.text: I'm traveling in London with a vegan, my Asian parents, my hubby and a 8 month old so trying to please everyone was going to be a challenge. Where was I going to find a place that was baby friendly, vegan friendly, and had a reasonably familiar menu for my parents?Cue Wagamama. They have high chairs and crayons for the baby (although he decided to try and eat those) and a vegan menu for my sister. My husband and I had the pork buns, the lettuce wraps, and a sirloin and shiitake salad along with two juices. Everything was incredibly fresh and delicious. It's a chain, but a very solid one at that. The only thing that was a bit spotty was our service that night. We were there at 8pm on a Friday night and were seated right away. Getting the attention of someone to get our order took a good 15 minutes though but our food did come out very quickly.

lbSq_tJ8HCNJ-xZ2RoaGWg.text: This restaurant is delicious. If you are in the London area, I highly recommend. The Asian cuisine is super good, and the ramen is delicious. The inside is vibrant, the service is very good, and the restaurants are located conveniently across Greater London. The sides and appetizers are delicious.

0zCyDDTXsdTz7hADY5dgXA.text: I've been to this Wagamama quite a lot as it has become our pre-cinema ritual if we're going to something at Leicester Square. Because I was running late, on this occasion we ended up going post-cinema instead.The restaurant was more empty than normal, because of the different time we arrived and there was some building work going on in the back. But there was also new menus - with new menu items. One caught my eye - a beef massaman curry. I love those - so I wasted no time in ordering it. The food as always was speedy, and arrived as it was ready, but I was disappointed in my curry. It just wasn't a massaman - it was edible, but not something I'd go out of my way to order ever again. In fact, I can't really describe it as I don't know what it was actually similar to. I ended up adding a bunch of things (soy sauce, those chilli flakes, the chilli oil) to make it more interesting to eat but nothing worked. The only time my tastebuds were at all interested in it were the bites when I had a sliced chilli in there.I wasn't happy with the beef either - it wasn't trimmed so there were chunks of fat at one each of each piece. I ended up biting the ends off and placing them in another bowl as I didn't want those! So yeah, don't order the massaman, but the staff here are lovely - they got the two stars on this visit. As the description for this level says, "meh, I've experienced better". So true for this visit.

2KNmmPxhHj4_EuBNyOvKGw.text: I absolutely love this place. Too bad the location near the British Museum has closed. But this location is also fantastic. And the food is just as delicious.

JUsILNwq4WCmeC8Ax-D9CA.text: Went 3 times in 6 days. Get their juices! The Supergreen is SO GOOD and refreshing after walking around and tourist-ing it all day. Edamame - yum.Pork ribs - yum!Chicken ramen - delicious, I got it mild. You can skip the broccoli and bok choy appetizer it was drenched in sauce. Good service and get their green tea - it's freeeeeeee!!!!!

UxPzJKZ5HA2em7dhGY6eLA.text: Pretty much standard westernized Asian fare.  Ordered the beef donburi ( rice, beef, kimchi) served in a bowl. Ramen is decent but far from transcendent.  Think of it as a safe bet if your out of other options.  Location is in the basement and is therefore windowless.  Not wheelchair accessible.

6KHBZcro_T5H-jJPV3wHKQ.text: Gonna go for a 3.5. Had my first Wagamama experience here while pressed for time. Pretty good for a chain.Location is pretty convenient to central, and it's nice that's right at Leicester Square. Nice, simple interior. You go down the steps to get to the main area. Service was not bad and pretty efficient. There's a good buzz and ambiance to these places, since the kitchen is partly open, so you feel like you're in the heat of the action.Food is your typical Asian fusion that tends towards Japanese. Got some yaki soba noodles that had just enough proteins and veg. The sister got something similar to that, both dishes not bad. A bit on the pricier side at about 8-9 pound each, but it's consistent.Being a US visitor to the UK, it was kind of funny to see another group of Americans sit down at the table next to us. I guess we like the same things hah.Will get this again if I'm in a hurry while visiting the UK!

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. some teppan-fried noodles
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. entranceway

PXePAAmJnOReiGDY1-xDWg.text: Food Rating:  3.5 starsWagamama was one of the first Asian Fusion chain restaurants I went to while studying abroad in London several years ago.  Naturally, when I went back to visit London, I had to make a pit stop!Overall, for Asian fusion, it's pretty good.  If you're looking for authenticity, then this is not the place.For this visit, my friend and I ordered the following:1) Duck Gyoza Appetizer - 5 deep fried duck dumplings, served with spicy cherry hoisin sauce - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…Dumplings were fried very well.  Filling was very flavorful.  My friend loved the spicy cherry hoisin sauce.2) Kare Lomen - ramen noodles in a spicy coconut and lemongrass soup topped with prawns, beansprouts, and cucumber.  Garnished with coriander and lime - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…Coconut broth was thicker almost like a sauce.3) Chicken Ramen - noodles in a chicken and pork soup topped with grilled chicken breast and seasonal greens.  Garnished with menma (picked bamboo shoots) and spring onions - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…Lighter flavored soup broth.4) Wine wine - great pairing with the lighter flavored noodle dishes - in this case, the wine was perfectly paired with the Chicken Ramen5) Passion Fruit Frozen Yoghurt - deliciously smooth with a tropical fruit finish - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…6) Chocolate Fudge Cake - served with dark chocolate wasabi sauce and vanilla pod ice cream - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…The wasabi flavor was light to the point where I would not have known there was wasabi if I hadn't read the menu.  The dark chocolate flavor is stronger and overpowers the wasabi flavor.Restaurant Pictures:1) Entrance - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…2) Seating - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…3) Communal Seating - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…4) Communal Seating - yelp.co.uk/biz_photos/Qu…Overall, good memories.  Worth a stop by if you're craving Asian Fusion noodles.*Note:  Communal dining.  Orders are taken on PDA's, which wirelessly sends orders to the kitchen.**Wagamama reminds me of Republic located in Union Square in New York City - yelp.com/biz/republic-ne…

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate Fudge Cake - served with dark chocolate wasabi sauce and vanilla pod ice cream
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Passion Fruit Frozen Yoghurt - deliciously smooth with a tropical fruit finish
Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom

nkRHKM8hM6m0qAird6lbTw.text: Firstly I want to mention the food at Wagamamas is amazing! This review is for this particular location. It was friday lunch and was really looking fwd to eating some noodles! We got in and were shown to our table....we then waited 30 mins trying to get the waiters attention....40 minutes had gone by....they had 3 people working including doing all the drinks! no one had even taken our drinks order so we had to leave.....what annoyed me the most is they had wasted a member of staff at the front door getting people to come in! We had to leave, they didn't even notice and then walked to the Covent Garden location....Fantastic!

nNf6sNM3wLwz9ZjtgIEiHA.text: This is the second time I've had this food and I was pleased with the flavor and the portions of the food. I have the rice-cury this time which had a coconut curry sauce mixed with chicken, lime, and vegetables. The flavors were intense and somewhat more Thai than Japanese. The service was great and the wait time was really fast. They also have a variety of freshly squeezes juices as well as a variety of drinks. We ce for the curried dishes and we are glad we did. Give this place a try next time you are in the area.

YD-dz0dWhFEtdTHJKDUvEw.text: Disgusting. I don't know why the other reviewers who are supposedly from ethnically diverse areas are lowering their standards so much, but what I had here hardly qualifies as 1.) Asian, 2.) Ramen, 3.) Edible.I ordered their ramen and the broth was watery, the noodles doughy, and the toppings completely inappropriate and mismatched to the dish. I could make a better ramen by tossing random leftovers in my fridge on top of instant noodles.The menu is an affront to Japanese food, and an affront to anyone who has had the pleasure of enjoying a proper bowl of ramen. This is the Panda Express of noodles. Even the nonsense-word, made-up, Asian sounding name is insulting. It seems like the Asian food scene in London is exploding lately, I encourage you to try any other of the plethora of options popping up. If you really want to treat yourself, try Nagomi for a legit bowl of ramen.

eA94Q2_JnL_0zWg_KAd4xg.text: Given that it's a fast food chain, I did not expect much. I had the wagamama ramen and the soup was surprisingly good. However, the ramen itself was a disappointment, seriously, it was not tender and lacked all the qualities that good ramen should have. The service itself was quick and friendly. The place itself resembled a cafeteria and you need to be comfortable with sitting next to strangers and listen to every words they say.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. wagamama ramen

vZe_tqaoRzrIfcrjYw3QoQ.text: The noodle is on the thin side and kinda doughy. The chicken broth is not very flavorful either. Elder flower sparkling was nice, though borderline too sweet.

photos.caption: Photo of Wagamama - London, United Kingdom. Wagamama ramen

4W3lhCo-Sz5GUWh61SqDxA.text: For a chain... its ok.  I can usually find something to eat, however, every time I go, there is always one ingredient in the main dishes that I'm not really a fan of... or I don't know what it even is.  The prices are high, but then again if you see the plate or bowl of food that comes out, it is pretty massive.I had the Pork Dumpling Soup (it was on the specials menu), the dumplings were nice, although not nearly as good as the ones I get in Chinatown.  There were also not a lot of dumplings and because of the size of the bowl and the amount of broth in the soup, the bowl seemed a little empty.  There were sausage slices in the soup, but beware... the sausage had quite a bit of spice to it and it completely caught me by surprise.  Overall it was nice, but I wouldn't order it again.The service was a bit slow and we had trouble getting someone to help us or to even bring us the bill.  I've eaten here twice and I wasn't really impressed with it either time.

D0P5A8mEQrH_v9LViK2sag.text: 3.5 - yep, I liked it.For chain food, it's pretty good and a nice change from gross pub meals. For what it is, prices are a little high but for a London tourist horrified by the exchange rate, it's one of the cheaper places to eat.I had chicken ramen and while I wasn't blown away, it was good. Everything came out fast and you could get in & out quickly, perfect for the busy tourist.

h8VqkvPQnIPC0kV4PQFQTA.text: Slightly overpriced.  I ordered the yakitori chicken and miso soup, and my friend ordered the ginger chicken udon.  All were pretty yummy, especially considering that I have not eaten anything close to Asian food for 3 months for my stay in Europe.  However, I could have totally cooked this up myself in my apartment given the right ingredients, so not exactly the best value for my meal.I think my friend and I also had a good experience at this location due to the fact that they did not have a line, so our wait was short for both the seating and food.  Weird how they have everyone dine by sharing a long table with strangers.  So awkward how I could easily overhear my neighbor's conversation.

FYvKnuO0M2KOGCC2LKc6yQ.text: Surprisingly good for an asian fast food chain. Food tastes fresh and healthy. I had the gyoza, cha han, and the donburi. all were pretty good besides the chicken and prawn cha han. There wasnt alot of flavor in that. the miso soup was good and the kimchi wasnt so bad either. the picked stuff that comes with the miso soup is good. the donburi was great. good amount of terriyaki and chicken and rice.the service of this place is kinda whack but the location is cool and so is the interior decor. im honestly surprised that i like this place

bB289oTOvmi9BYNjVr0vjA.text: Good food and the service is quick and reasonably priced.Just a few things to point out. You could be sitting next to people you don't know and they are close enough to hear your conversation. So if you want to discuss anything personal/private don't do it here. Also, the food is delivered when cooked. This is okay but my food came a good 10 minutes before my partners, so it was a little dis-jointed. Saying that, this is an advantage if you want to eat quickly to say catch a show or something like that.

0dHceCjJPcu2TwnLW9qFTA.text: Why we don't have this in the states??? What a great asian fusion noodle place.  I had the chili chicken soup bowl with udon noodles - hot and yummy.  I would go back here again.  Service was super fast as well.
